qas.question: Who was a big proponent of modernism in art?
When did artists start to immigrate to Mexico City?
Who was a famous engraver that migrated to Mexico City?
What was the Popular Graphics Workshop mission?

answers.text: help blue-collar workers find a venue to express their art

context: During the <a1_0>20th century<a1_0/>, many artists immigrated to Mexico City from different regions of Mexico, such as <a2_0>Leopoldo Méndez<a2_0/>, an engraver from Veracruz, who supported the creation of the socialist Taller de la Gráfica Popular (Popular Graphics Workshop), designed to <a3_0>help blue-collar workers find a venue to express their art<a3_0/>. Other painters came from abroad, such as <a4_0>Catalan<a4_0/> painter Remedios Varo and other Spanish and Jewish exiles. It was in the second half of the 20th century that the artistic movement began to drift apart from the Revolutionary theme. <a0_0>José Luis Cuevas<a0_0/> opted for a modernist style in contrast to the muralist movement associated with social politics.
